gurmukhi: Awjwn bwhu AiqsY pRBwv ] AibXkq qyj sMnXws rwv ] jhN jhN ibhwr muin krq d`q ] AnBau pRkwS Aru ibml m`q ]170]
transliteration: Aajaan Baah(u) Atisai Prabhaav|| Abiyakat Tej Sannyaas Raav|| Jahan Jahan Bihaar Mounndi) Karat Datt|| Anbhau Prakaadh Ar(u) Bimal Matt||170||
translation: The glory of that king of Sannyasis was indescribable and the impact of his long arms was enormous; wherever the sage Dutt went, there also the effulgence glistened and the pure intellect extended.170.

gurmukhi: jy huqy dys dysn niRpwl ] qij grb pwn lwgy suFwl ] qij dIn Aaur JUTy aupwie ] diRV gihE eyk sMnXws rwie ]171]
transliteration: Je Houte Des Desan Nripaal|| Taj(i) Gadab Paan Laage Sudhaal|| Taj(i) Din Aur Jhoothe Oupaae|| Drid Gadio Ek Sannyaas Raae||171||
translation: The kings of the countries far and near, forsaking their pride came and fell at his feet; they abandoned all the false measures and with determination, made Dutt, the king ofYogis, as their base.171.

gurmukhi: qij srb Aws iek Aws ic`q ] Aibkwr ic`q prmM piv`q ] jh krq dys dysn ibhwr ] auT clq srb rwjw Apwr ]172]
transliteration: Taj(i) Sarab Aas Ik Aas Chitt|| Abikaar Chitt Paramannd Pavitt|| Jah Karat Des Desan Bihaar|| Outh Chalat Sarab Raajaa Apaar||172||
translation: Relinquishing all other desires, only one desire of meeting the Lord remained in their heart and the mind of all of them was supremely pure and without any vice; to whichever country Dutt went, the king of that place fell t his feet.172.

gurmukhi: gvn krq ijhN idSw mun mnu d`q Apwr ] sMig clq auiT sB pRjw qj Gr bwr phwr ]173]
transliteration: Gadan Karat Jihan Dishaa Min Man(u) Datt Apaar|| San(i) Chalat Outh Sabh Prajaa Taj Ghar Baar Pahaar||173||
translation: To whichever direction, Dutt went, the subjects of those places left their homes and accompanied him.173.

gurmukhi: ijh ijh dys munISr gey ] aUc nIc sBhI sMig Bey ] eyk jog Ar rUp Apwrw ] kaun n mohY kho ibcwrw ]174]
transliteration: Jih Tih Des Mounndeshar Gad|| Ooch Neech Sabh-hisan(i) Bhae|| Ek Jog Ar Roop Apaaraa|| Kaoun Na Mohai Kaho Bichaaraa||174||
translation: To whichever country, the great sage Dutt went, all the elders and minors accompanied him; whereas he was a Yogi, he was also extremely beautiful, then who would there be without allurement.174.

gurmukhi: jh qh clw jogu sMnXwsw ] rwj pwt qj Bey audwsw ] AYsI BUm n dyKIAq koeI ] jhw sMnXws jog nhI hoeI ]175]
transliteration: Jih Tah Chalaa Jog(u) Sannyaasaa|| Raaj Paat Taj Bhae Udaasaa|| Aisibhoom Na Dekheeat Koee|| Jahaa Sannyaas Jog Nahihoee||175||
translation: Wherever the impact of his Yoga and Sannyas reached, the people left all their paraphernalia and became unattached; no such place was visible, where there was not the impact of Yoga and Sannyas.175.

gurmukhi: ieq mn nUM gur dUsr ThrwieAw smwpqM ]2]
transliteration: It Man Noon Doosar Thahraaiaa Samaaptan||2||
translation: End of the adoption of Man (mind) as the second Guru.
Now begins the description of adopting Spider as the Third Guru

gurmukhi: caubIs gurU kIn ijh Bwqw ] Ab sun lyhu khO ieh bwqw ] eyk mkrkw d`q inhwrI ] AYs hiRdy Anumwn ibcwrI ]176]
transliteration: Chaoubees Guroo Keen Jih Bhaataa|| Ab Soun Leh(u) Kahau Eh Baataa|| Ek Makarkaa Datt Nihdaree|| Ais Hride Anoumaan Bichdaree||176||
translation: Listen not to the manner in which Dutt adopted twenty-four Gurus; He saw a spider and reflected in his mind.176.
